evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is observable and can be identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the cardinality_experiment baseline_singletons scenario.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew remains valid and is not invalidated by potential defeaters in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the cardinality_experiment baseline_singletons scenario.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features and characteristics expected in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the cardinality_experiment baseline_singletons scenario.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is observable and can be identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the cardinality_experiment baseline_singletons scenario.

assumptions: Crew communication and coordination are inferred from reported interactions and lack of warnings
No overriding mechanical or environmental factors caused the incident
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident
If mechanical failure or environmental marking deficiencies were primary causes

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 describe communication lapses and assumptions among crew members during pushback, supporting observable coordination breakdown in the scenario.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in interpreting crew intentions and signaling effectiveness

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure is present and relevant in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 baseline singletons scenario.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is present and relevant in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 baseline singletons scenario.

assumptions: No mechanical fault was reported or detected in the evidence
Operator actions and communications were accurately reported
defeaters: If fault codes or hardware malfunctions were found indicating control system failure
If physical evidence showed mechanical malfunction during pushback

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H2, H8, H12) indicates the pushback was controlled by operators with no mention of mechanical or control failure; the aircraft moving beyond the TRP (H4) occurred despite operator control, suggesting procedural deviation rather than mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of explicit mechanical fault evidence; ambiguity whether slow movement beyond TRP was due to mechanical failure or operator error

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft as per the baseline singletons cardinality experiment.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The environmental or marking deficiency must be resistant to defeaters, ensuring its validity and persistence within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA baseline singletons cardinality experiment.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the baseline singletons cardinality experiment.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft as per the baseline singletons cardinality experiment.

assumptions: The TRP marking described applies specifically to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft in the baseline singletons cardinality experiment
The presence of the TRP marking constitutes an environmental or marking deficiency if it is inadequate or insufficiently visible
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were missing or not visible on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft during the baseline singletons cardinality experiment
If procedural errors or communication failures were conclusively shown to be the sole cause without any marking deficiency

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7, H8, and H13 directly describe the presence and visibility of the TRP marking on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft's pushback area, supporting that the environmental or marking deficiency was present and identifiable.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in the sufficiency of visual signals and small size of TRP marking

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the 12-25 cardinality experiment baseline singletons context.

assumptions: The procedural deviation is defined by the tug instructor's failure to stop at the TRP despite known procedures.
Communication between crew was adequate but did not prevent the deviation.
defeaters: If evidence showed the tug instructor was responding to a communication failure or environmental factors rather than procedural deviation.
If the headset operator or wingman had explicitly warned or intervened to prevent the deviation but were ignored.
If mechanical or environmental factors forced the pushback beyond the TRP.

outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit evidence on environmental or mechanical factors; some ambiguity in communication effectiveness.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution remains valid and is not invalidated by any known defeaters within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 cardinality experiment baseline singletons setting.

children_spec.statement: Crew adherence to standard pushback checklist procedures

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be resistant to defeaters, ensuring its validity and persistence within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA baseline singletons cardinality experiment.

assumptions: The environmental or marking deficiency refers to the TRP marking and its visibility or recognition
Defeater resistance implies the marking should prevent or alert crew to stop pushback reliably
defeaters: If there was evidence that the TRP markings were highly visible and unmistakable under all conditions
If crew had effective, reliable communication and alerting methods that prevented passing the TRP
If the environmental markings were confirmed to be compliant with standards and visible to all involved

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.
He assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
The TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H8, H11, H12, H13) indicates that communication and visual signals were insufficient to prevent the pushback past the TRP, supporting that the environmental or marking deficiency was not resistant to defeaters, thus validating the claim in the context.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in the sufficiency of marking visibility and communication effectiveness

node.statement: Pushback equipment functioned correctly without mechanical faults

assumptions: No mechanical faults were reported or observed during the event
Operator statements about tug function are accurate and complete
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical faults or bench checks indicating tug malfunction
If the tug equipment had failed or was unresponsive during pushback

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 and H12 indicate no mechanical faults or equipment malfunction; the tug instructor controlled the pushback and the tug slowed but did not stop as expected, supporting that equipment functioned correctly and the issue was procedural.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct mechanical inspection reports provided; assumption based on operator statements and observed behavior

assumptions: No mechanical faults were reported or detected in the evidence.
Communication and coordination issues are sufficient to explain the event.
defeaters: If there were verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions indicating hardware faults.
If physical evidence showed mechanical malfunction or control system failure.

node.statement: Crew members have sufficient time and opportunity to engage in communication and coordination

defeaters: If evidence showed that communication means were unavailable or that crew were distracted or incapacitated, or if environmental factors prevented effective communication, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3, H8, H10, and H12 show crew members had communication means and opportunities, including interphone use and direct interaction, supporting that they had sufficient time and opportunity to engage in communication and coordination.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity exists about the effectiveness of communication signals (H8) and whether all crew members actively communicated warnings, but overall communication opportunity was present.

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA are maintained in a legible and undamaged condition

node.statement: Communication devices and channels are operational and available for use by the crew

assumptions: Operational communication devices imply availability for use
No evidence of device malfunction implies devices were functional
defeaters: If evidence showed communication devices were non-operational or unavailable
If hardware faults or environmental marking deficiencies were documented affecting communication

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H8, and H12 show communication devices were operational and used, but communication breakdown occurred among crew, supporting the claim that communication devices and channels were available but coordination failed.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew behavior interpretation and lack of explicit device status reports

node.statement: All required environmental markings are present and visible on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA

assumptions: TRP and other required environmental markings are as described in H7 and H13 and are visible
No evidence of marking damage or obscuration was reported or found
defeaters: If evidence showed that TRP or other required markings were missing or obscured
If crew or ground personnel reported inability to see or identify markings
If physical inspection revealed damaged or non-visible markings
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates missing or non-visible environmental markings on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA; the TRP markings are known and present (H7, H13). The incident involved procedural deviations and communication breakdowns (H8, H10, H12) rather than marking deficiencies. Physical evidence of aircraft collision (H4, H6) supports mechanical or procedural causes, not marking absence.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of explicit direct evidence confirming marking visibility; reliance on indirect inference from procedural and communication evidence

node.statement: All required environmental markings are accessible and not obstructed on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA

assumptions: TRP markings on taxiway are representative of environmental markings relevant to the aircraft.
No other environmental markings were deficient beyond the TRP.
defeaters: If evidence showed markings were physically obstructed or inaccessible on the aircraft or taxiway.
If crew reported inability to see or identify the TRP markings during pushback.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 and H13 indicate the TRP marking exists and is visible, though small, suggesting markings were accessible and not obstructed, contradicting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in marking size and visibility; no direct statement confirming obstruction or accessibility

node.statement: Crew adherence to standard pushback checklist procedures

assumptions: Standard pushback checklist procedures include instructor taking over when trainee requests and visual/communication signals as described.
defeaters: If evidence showed the crew ignored standard checklist steps or failed to communicate critical stop signals, this would challenge procedural adherence.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H2, H3, H8, H10, H12) shows crew actions consistent with adherence to standard pushback procedures, with the instructor taking control and the trainee deferring, supporting the claim of procedural adherence and distinguishing it from communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in interpreting crew communication effectiveness and whether all checklist steps were followed exactly.

node.statement: Communication between ground crew and flight crew was clear and unambiguous during pushback

assumptions: Communication via interphone and visual signals is considered clear and unambiguous
No evidence of communication failure is present in the provided history
defeaters: If evidence showed miscommunication or ambiguous signals between ground and flight crew during pushback
If headset operator or wingman had failed to communicate critical information

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H8, and H12 indicate that communication between ground crew and flight crew was maintained and clear, with no warnings or signals missed, supporting the claim of clear and unambiguous communication during pushback.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in interpreting non-verbal signals and assumptions about situational awareness

node.statement: Environmental conditions did not interfere with pushback procedure execution

assumptions: TRP markings and environmental conditions were adequate and visible as no evidence suggests otherwise.
defeaters: If evidence showed poor visibility or inadequate TRP markings or environmental factors causing confusion, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H8, H10, H12, H13) indicates no environmental interference such as poor marker visibility or inadequate signaling that would have prevented proper pushback execution, supporting the claim that environmental conditions did not interfere.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct mention of adverse environmental conditions; assumption that TRP visibility and environmental factors were adequate based on operator comments.

node.statement: Environmental markings on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA are maintained in a legible and undamaged condition

defeaters: If evidence showed damaged or illegible environmental markings on the aircraft
If there were reports or observations of marking deficiencies contributing to the incident
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates that environmental markings on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA are illegible or damaged; evidence focuses on procedural and communication issues.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure withstands potential defeaters within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 baseline singletons setting.

assumptions: No direct mechanical fault evidence is present in the provided history.
Communication was effective as no failures or missed warnings were reported.
Procedural adherence was generally followed given no explicit deviations reported.
defeaters: If evidence showed a confirmed mechanical fault or control malfunction, it would strengthen mechanical failure claim.
If communication logs or recordings showed breakdown or missed warnings, it would favor communication failure.
If procedural deviations or operator errors were documented, it would favor procedural deviation.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows communication was maintained (H1, H8, H12) and no procedural deviation was evident (H8, H10, H12), favoring mechanical failure over communication or procedural causes. However, environmental factors like small TRP markings and lack of marshalling wands (H4, H7, H13) suggest environment deficiency could also explain the event, leading to neutral entailment.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity due to overlapping possible causes: environment deficiencies vs mechanical failure; lack of direct mechanical fault evidence.

children_spec.statement: Environmental factors interfered with communication signals among crew

assumptions: The TRP ground markings are the correct procedural stop point
The absence of warnings from wingman and headset operator indicates procedural deviation rather than communication failure

If communication signals were clearly given and acknowledged but ignored due to other factors
availability.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast barrier, indicating procedural deviation. H8, H10, and H12 describe communication and signaling issues that support procedural deviation over communication breakdown, favoring the procedural deviation hypothesis.
availability.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in communication effectiveness and possible unreported mechanical issues

assumptions: The absence of mechanical fault evidence implies no mechanical control failure
Communication and environmental factors were sufficiently monitored and reported in the evidence
defeaters: If evidence showed that communication breakdowns or environmental deficiencies were the primary cause rather than procedural deviation
If mechanical control failures were documented affecting pushback

defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1-H4, H8, H10, H12) shows the procedural deviation in pushback execution was deliberate and not invalidated by communication failures or environmental deficiencies; no mechanical control failure evidence was found, supporting the claim.
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of mechanical control failure; some ambiguity in communication effectiveness but no contradicting evidence to procedural deviation validity.

assumptions: The procedural deviation is defined by the tug instructor's failure to stop at the TRP despite known procedures.
Communication between crew was adequate but did not prevent the deviation.

If the headset operator or wingman had explicitly warned or intervened to prevent the deviation but were ignored.

fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence (H1-H4, H8-H12) shows the procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA context, with the tug instructor's actions and communication patterns consistent with procedural deviation rather than communication breakdown.
fit_to_key_features.uncertainty_source: No explicit evidence on environmental or mechanical factors; some ambiguity in communication effectiveness.

assumptions: No significant mechanical or environmental failures contributed to the incident

defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H8, H10, H12) shows lack of effective communication and coordination among crew during pushback, leading to the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier (H4), supporting the communication/coordination breakdown claim and not invalidated by potential defeaters.
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew intentions and possible unreported communications

assumptions: The scenario baseline_singletons includes typical crew communication expectations for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA.

The discriminator disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN favors communication breakdown over procedural deviation.
